description:
On the first day of Shell my true love gave to me
A list of files in the directory tree ...
learn:
You've stumbled upon a festive adventure where you need to type single commands into your browser to get Christmas presents! As a reward for your efforts, you might learn a little bit about the command line. On just about every Unix and Unix-like operating systems there is a command named `ls`.
`ls` is short for "list" and can be used to list files in your current working directory. Try sending the command `ls` in the command box to list all files in the directory.

description:
On the second day of Shell my true love gave to me
Two lines a-laughing ...
--- _Hint: look for lines that contain the string "laugh"_

_If you aren't sure what to do, expand the "learn" section above._
_You can also view user solutions by expanding "View Solutions" above_
learn:
What's so funny? Let's look for lines in our Christmas poem that are laughing. `grep` is the most common command-line utility for extracting text from a file.
The syntax of the command is `grep PATTERN `.
`PATTERN` is a string, and refers to a [basic regular expression](https://www.gnu.org/software/sed/manual/html_node/BRE-syntax.html).
All you need to know for now is to set `PATTERN` to the string you are looking for. In this example you might try: ``` grep laugh night-before-christmas.txt ``` Which will print every single line that contains the string "laugh".
There are many options for the `grep` command, for example to do a case-insensitive search you would type: ``` grep -i laugh night-before-christmas.txt ``` To see all available options check out the man page by sending the command `man grep` or the help `grep --help`.

lines: That shook when he laughed, like a bowlful of jelly.
And I laughed when I saw him, in spite of myself;

description:
On the third day of Shell my true love gave to me
Three lines at the beginning ...
learn:
When you have a text file, it's common to only need to see the top N lines.
Included in most Unix-like systems is a utility named `head`.
By default, it will display the first 10 lines of the file.

To display the first 3 lines, you will need to use the option `-n 3`.

Try sending the command:

```
head -n 3 night-before-christmas.txt
```

lines: 'Twas the night before Christmas, when all through the house
Not a creature was stirring, not even a mouse;
The stockings were hung by the chimney with care

description:
On the fourth day of Shell my true love gave to me
Four lines at the end ...
learn:
Just like we needed to look at the beginning lines on day three, a utility called `tail` can be used to look at the bottom N lines.
By default it will display the last 10 lines so like before you will need to use the `-n` option.

```
tail -n 4 night-before-christmas.txt
```

lines: He sprang to his sleigh, to his team gave a whistle,
And away they all flew like the down of a thistle.
But I heard him exclaim, ere he drove out of sight,
"Happy Christmas to all, and to all a good-night."

description:
On the fifth day of Shell my true love gave to me
Five lines that start with "the" ...
learn:
We already used `grep` to extract a string from a file earlier so if you were thinking we would use `grep` again you are on the right track! Here we want to find all lines that start with the word "the". One way you could do this is look for a capital "T" since the beginning of every sentence is capatilized.
Since `grep` is case sensitive by default, one way would be to search for the string `The` We mentioned early that the PATTERN in `grep PATTERN ` refers to a [basic regular expression](https://www.gnu.org/software/sed/manual/html_node/BRE-syntax.html).
This allows to do more than simple string matches by using the basic regular expression syntax.
One example is the `^` character which will anchor the search to the start of every string.
This type of character is called a [regex anchor](https://www.regular-expressions.info/anchors.html).
To do a case-insenstive search for the word `the` but only match it at the _beginning_ of every line, you will need to use a combination of `-i` for case insenstive match and an `^` anchor. For example: ``` grep -i "^the" night-before-christmas.txt ``` Try it below!

lines: The stockings were hung by the chimney with care
The children were nestled all snug in their beds,
The moon on the breast of the new-fallen snow
The prancing and pawing of each little hoof.
The stump of a pipe he held tight in his teeth,

description:
On the sixth day of Shell my true love gave to me
Six lines that are exciting! ...
--- _Hint: Exciting lines end with "!"_
learn:
To find "exciting" lines we want to only print lines that end with a `!` character.
Just like how previously we learned that regular expression syntax can match strings with an anchor at the beginning of the line we can use `$` to anchor the match at the end. ``` grep '!$' night-before-christmas.txt ``` One important thing to be aware of is that the character `!` is a [special character](https://www.oreilly.com/library/view/learning-the-bash/1565923472/ch01s09.html) for the shell.
To ensure that this works correctly you will need to either use single-quotes like above, or escape it with a `\`: ``` grep \!$ night-before-christmas.txt ```

lines: Now, Dasher! now, Dancer! now, Prancer and Vixen!
On, Comet! on, Cupid! on, Donder and Blitzen!
To the top of the porch! to the top of the wall!
Now dash away! dash away! dash away all!
His eyes--how they twinkled! his dimples how merry!
His cheeks were like roses, his nose like a cherry!

disp_title: Seven files that start with Santa
description:
On the seventh day of Shell my true love gave to me
Seven files that start with "Santa" ...
learn:
Now there are more than just one file in the working directory. Like the first day, we will need to use the `ls` command to list them.
Unlike before, we need to limit the output to only files that begin with the string "Santa".
To do this, we will need to use a feature of most shells that is called wildcarding or [globbing](https://tldp.org/LDP/abs/html/globbingref.html). To create a wildcard, you will use the `*` character which will match zero or more characters after the string.
For example, to match anything that starts with the string "Santa" you will need to send: ``` ls Santa* ``` If you wanted to list files that start with "Santa" or "santa" there is another feature you can use that can match multiple characters called [ranges](https://tldp.org/LDP/Bash-Beginners-Guide/html/sect_04_03.html).
For example: ``` ls [Ss]anta* ``` Will match both files named `Santa's hat` and `santa's toys`.

description:
On the eighth day of Shell my true love gave to me
Eight elves in Santa's Workhop/ ...
--- _Hint: Try finding files named after Elves and moving them to the Workshop/ directory._
learn:
The elves are lost and only you can help them get back into Santa's workshop! You can see where they are by sending the command `ls Elves/`. This will list all the files in the "Elves/" directory. To move them to the `Workhop/` we will need to use the `mv` command and the `*` wildcard that was used on Day 7. The `mv` command will move one more more files from one location to a new one.
If you specify multiple files, all the files will be moved to the last argument which is the destination. For example: ``` mv file1 file2 file3 destination/ ``` Will move all three files to the folder named `destination/` To move every file in in `Elves/` we can use a wildcard `Elves/*`, and move them by sending the following command: ``` mv Elves/* Workshop/ ```

description:
On the ninth day of Shell my true love gave to me
Nine names of Santa's Reindeer ...
learn:
Santa's nine Reindeer are lost in sub-directories, can you find them? Here we introduce a common utility called `find` which as you can probably guess, is used to find files. The Reindeer are hiding in sub-directories, to search for them in the current directory we use `.` as the first option to `find`. `.` is just another way of specifying the current working directory that you are in. Try sending: ``` find . ``` This will find both directories **and** files which is not what we want.
In order to display only files, you will need to use the `-type f` argument to `find`: ``` find . -type f ```

description:
On the tenth day of Shell my true love gave to me
Ten Lords by their names sorted ...
learn:
The Ten Lords are all mixed up!

Sorting is something we do often on the command line.
There is a file named `lords.txt` that contains a list of lords. We can
use the command `sort` to sort the contents and print them, by default
it will sort the file in dictionary order.

```
sort lords.txt
```

description:
On the eleventh day of Shell my true love gave to me
Eleven lines with pipers ‚ô´ piping ‚ô´ ...
learn:
The pipers are playing their pipes but also other music, can you print the piping music? Here we find ourselves in a directory with files named `piper`, each file with one line matching the string "‚ô´ piping ‚ô´".
To only output the lines that match "‚ô´ piping ‚ô´" we will need to first find the files that contain the string, and then output their contents. Earlier we used the `find` command to find files, here we will use it again to find files named `piper`: ``` find . -name "piper" -type f ``` To look for specific strings in each `find` result, the `-exec` can be used to execute a command for every file found. The special string `{}` can be used as a substitute for the filename. For example: ``` find . -name "piper" -type f -exec grep piping {} \; ``` will search for the string "piping" and execute `grep` in every file that find returns. The `\;` is an escaped `;` that ends the command that is executed. There are a lot of different ways to get the same result, see the solutions for more examples. It's even possible to play the pipers piping using a pipe!

description:
On the twelfth day of Shell my true love gave to me
Twelve Days of Shell on the terminal!
learn:
We have reached the twelfth day of Shell!
For the final day all you need to do is print out the contents of `twelve-days-of-shell.txt`. If you enjoyed these exercises [follow us on twitter](https://twitter.com/thecmdchallenge) or try more [command line challenges](https://cmdchallenge.com)!

lines: On the twelfth day of Shell my true love gave to me
Twelve days of Shell on the terminal
Ten lords by their names sorted
And a list of files in the directory tree

description:
A process on this computer managed to delete all of the files in
the /bin and /usr/bin directories!

---
The good news is that you still have a shell prompt, the bad news
is that you are only able to execute one command to complete each challenge.

For now, all you need to do is figure out where you are,
print the current working directory.

Great, now that you know which directory you are in, you want to see what else
is here. List all of the files on a single line, in the current working directory.

Hint: You won't be able to use the `ls` command, instead you will need to use
a bash builtin

Oh no! You now remember there is a very important file in this directory.

Display its contents before the data is lost for forever!
example: while read x; do echo $x; done < my-dissertation.txt

lines: Rooter: A Methodology for the Typical Unification
Jeremy Stribling, Daniel Aguayo and Maxwell Krohn
Many physicists would agree that, had it not been for
congestion control, the evaluation of web browsers might never
have occurred. In fact, few hackers worldwide would disagree
with the essential uniÔ¨Åcation of voice-over-IP and public-
private key pair. In order to solve this riddle, we conÔ¨Årm that
SMPs can be made stochastic, cacheable, and interposable.

description:
You know there is a process on machine that is deleting files, the first thing
you want to do is identify the name of it. Print the name of the process

Hint: process information is stored in /proc, maybe there is a something there
that will help?

You are doing great!

You managed to save your important file.
Now that you know the process name
it will be good to kill it before it does any more damanage.

Kill the running process

author: cmdchallenge
description:
Your first challenge is to print "hello world" on the terminal in a single command.

Hint: There are many ways to print text on the command line, one way is with the 'echo' command.
Try it below and good luck!

author: cmdchallenge
description: Print the current working directory.

author: cmdchallenge
description: List names of all the files in the current directory, one file per line.

author: cmdchallenge
description: There is a file named `access.log` in the current directory. Print the contents.

author: cmdchallenge
description: Print the last 5 lines of "access.log".

author: cmdchallenge
description: Create an empty file named `take-the-command-challenge` in the current working directory.

author: cmdchallenge
description:
Create a directory named `tmp/files` in the current working directory
---
_Hint: The directory "`tmp/`" doesn't exist, with one command you need to create both "`tmp/`" and "`tmp/files`"_

author: cmdchallenge
description: Copy the file named `take-the-command-challenge` to the directory `tmp/files`

author: cmdchallenge
description: Move the file named `take-the-command-challenge` to the directory `tmp/files`

author: cmdchallenge
description:
A symbolic link is a type of file that is a reference to another file.

Create a symbolic link named `take-the-command-challenge` that points to the
file `tmp/files/take-the-command-challenge`.

author: cmdchallenge
description:
Delete all of the files in this challenge directory including all subdirectories and their contents.
---
_Hint: There are files and directories that start with a dot "`.`", "`rm -rf *`" won't work here!_

author: cmdchallenge
description:
There are files in this challenge with different file extensions.
Remove all files with the .doc extension recursively in the current working directory.

author: cmdchallenge
description: There is a file named `access.log` in the current working directory. Print all lines in this file that contains the string "GET".

author: cmdchallenge
description: Print all files in the current directory, one per line (not the path, just the filename) that contain the string "500".

author: cmdchallenge
description: Print the relative file paths, one path per line for all filenames that start with "access.log" in the current directory.

author: cmdchallenge
description:
Print all matching lines (without the filename or the file path) in all files under the current directory that start with "access.log" that contain the string "500".

Note that there are no files named `access.log` in the current directory, you will need to search recursively.

author: cmdchallenge
description: Extract all IP addresses from files that start with "access.log" printing one IP address per line.

author: cmdchallenge
description: Count the number of files in the current working directory. Print the number of files as a single integer.

author: cmdchallenge
description: Print the contents of access.log sorted.

author: cmdchallenge
description: Print the number of lines in access.log that contain the string "GET".

author: cmdchallenge
description:
The file split-me.txt contains a list of numbers separated by a `;` character.

Split the numbers on the `;` character, one number per line.

author: cmdchallenge
description: Print the numbers 1 to 100 separated by spaces.

author: cmdchallenge
description:
This challenge has text files (with a .txt extension) that contain the phrase "challenges are difficult".  Delete this phrase from all text files recursively.

Note that some files are in subdirectories so you will need to search for them.

author: cmdchallenge
description: The file sum-me.txt has a list of numbers, one per line. Print the sum of these numbers.

author: cmdchallenge
description: Print all files in the current directory recursively without the leading directory path.

author: cmdchallenge
description: Rename all files removing the extension from them in the current directory recursively.
example: for f in $(find . -type f -name "*.*"); do mv "$f" "${f%.*}"; done

author: cmdchallenge
description:
The files in this challenge contain spaces.
List all of the files (filenames only) in the current directory but replace all spaces with
a '.' character.

author: cmdchallenge
description:
In this challenge there are some directories containing files with different extensions.
Print all directories, one per line without duplicates that contain one or more files with a ".tf" extension.

author: cmdchallenge
description:
There are a mix of files in this directory that start with letters and numbers.
Print the filenames (just the filenames) of all files that start with a number recursively in the current directory.

author: cmdchallenge
description: Print the 25th line of the file faces.txt

author: cmdchallenge
description:
Print the lines of the file `reverse-me.txt` in this directory in reverse line order so that the last line is printed first and the first line is printed last.

```
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
In the future
Environmental destruction will be the norm
No longer can it be said that
My peers and I care about this earth
It will be evident that
My generation is apathetic and lethargic
It is foolish to presume that
There is hope
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
-Jonathan Reed "The Lost Generation"
```

lines: It is foolish to presume that
My generation is apathetic and lethargic
My peers and I care about this earth
No longer can it be said that
Environmental destruction will be the norm

author: cmdchallenge
description:
Print the file faces.txt, but only print the first instance of each duplicate line, even if the duplicates don't appear next to each other.

Note that order matters so don't sort the lines before removing duplicates.

author: cmdchallenge
example: for num in $(cat random-numbers.txt); do [[ $num == $(factor $num | cut -d" " -f2) ]] && echo $num; done | sort | uniq | wc -l
description:
The file `random-numbers.txt` contains a list of 100 random integers.
Print the number of unique prime numbers contained in the file.

author: amboar
description:
`access.log.1` and `access.log.2` are http server logs.

Print the IP addresses common to both files, one per line.

author: mmr
description:
Print all matching lines (without the filename or the file path) in all files under the current directory that start with "access.log", where the next line contains the string "404".

Note that you will need to search recursively.

author: anonymous
example: for i in $(ls *.bin); do if [[ `cmp base.bin $i` ]]; then echo $i; fi; done
description: Print all files with a `.bin` extension in the current directory that are different than the file named base.bin.

author: gitunique
description:
There is a file: `./.../  /. .the flag.txt`

Show its contents on the screen.

author: anonymous
description: How many lines contain tab characters in the file named `file-with-tabs.txt` in the current directory.

author: bryfry
description:
There are files in this challenge with different file extensions.

Remove all files without the .txt and .exe extensions recursively in the current working directory.

author: anonymous
disp_title: Remove files that start with a dash
description: There are some files in this directory that start with a dash in the filename.  Remove those files.

author: verovan
disp_title: Print the content sorted by PID
description: There are two files in this directory, ps-ef1 and ps-ef2.  Print the contents of both files sorted by PID and delete repeated lines.
example: cat ps-ef1 > aux; sed '1 d' ps-ef2 >> aux; cat aux | sort -nk2,2 | uniq

lines: UID        PID  PPID  C STIME TTY          TIME CMD

author: TaTo69
description:
In the current directory there is a file called netstat.out.

Print all the IPv4 listening ports sorted from the higher to lower.
